slides.title: A Time of Tremendous Upheaval
content: Hitler felt born in a time devoid of heroism, destined for peaceful competition instead of glory, creating feelings of ill-luck.
The Boer War provided a distant spark of action; he was a keen follower of that heroic struggle from afar with great enthusiasm.
The Russo-Japanese War increased his sense of national pride, taking Japan's side against Austria's Slavism enemy, the Russian nation.
Europe was experiencing a moment of heightened tension and foreboding, creating a sense of impending and unavoidable catastrophe.
slides.script: Hello everyone, welcome to our discussion on Chapter 5 of Mein Kampf, 'The World War.' This chapter focuses on Hitler's perspective of the events surrounding the onset of World War I and his enlistment. We'll begin by examining the feelings around the coming war, the long period of peace that preceded it and Hitler's own feeling of excitement at war's eruption. Before the war, Hitler saw the world as bland. It would come as a surprise to him when it erupted into action again.

slides.title: The Spark Ignites: Sarajevo
content: The assassination of Archduke Franz Fer dinand triggered a seismic change, with Austria issuing a dire ultimatum.
Austria's action was seen as an inevitable response; any other nation would have responded similarly, given the provocation.
However, Hitler believed Germany's struggle was not about Austria, but about German freedom, German independence and its future.
Hitler found himself grateful and ecstatic for the opportunity to prove his national fervour as a man of great sacrifice.
slides.script: Here, we'll take a closer look at the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, the trigger for the first World War, and how it transformed the world from bland to a source of purpose for Hitler. Hitler saw Germany as being at stake, not simply the Archduke's assassination or the potential loss of Austrian Slav territories. The assassination gave him the opportunity to prove his patriotism through action.

slides.title: From Enthusiasm to Grim Resolve
content: Initial romanticism gave way to horror at the front, causing enthusiasm to cool as soldiers faced constant death and privation.
Internal conflict arose between self-preservation and duty, yet the call of duty ultimately prevailed over his own fears.
Though transformed from laughing volunteer to a resolved veteran, he believed that similar transformation occurred across the army.
Hitler's emotional state changed at the front; it wasn't just his own feelings that transformed, but the feelings he was witnessing around him.
slides.script: This slide illustrates the shift in Hitler's perspective as he experienced the realities of war. The realities of war changed people, and as a man at the front, Hitler's view was no different. The front became the primary focus for him and his unit as the glamour of it all faded.

slides.title: Wartime Concerns: Propaganda
content: Hitler observes the effective propaganda used by the enemy, contrasting it with inadequate German efforts, giving him a focus for reform.
The importance of understanding psychology, or the human mind, would be key to Hitler's perspective on propaganda.
The British used tales of German barbarity, preparing their soldiers and strengthening their resolve; there was great success.
Germany's inability to provide realistic news led to troops distrusting their leaders, ultimately affecting army morale.
slides.script: Now we'll examine Hitler's budding awareness of the power of propaganda and mass communication. The success of the Allied propaganda was clear to see for Hitler. He noted how important it was to the war, and how Germany was struggling by comparison. Even here at the front, politics had crept in.

slides.title: Wartime Concerns: Weakness at Home
content: Hitler grew more concerned with home-front weaknesses: moral decay, 'lack of patriotic enthusiasm', and undermining German unity.
Our bourgeois class is so out of touch, as are the 'national' leaders who cannot unite our forces due to their ignorance.
Propaganda via media like smutty theatre, cinema, and newspapers spread through people, and no knowledge of country is inculcated.
These weaknesses are the product of a lack of patriotic education, with schools more concerned about objective neutrality.
slides.script: Here, we'll explore Hitler's growing disillusionment with the state of affairs on the home front. According to Hitler, a good patriotic education is crucial for maintaining moral and civic virtue within the nation. He notes that all too often the people at the home front lack this, leading to the internal and external collapse of Germany.

slides.title: The Social Democrats
content: Hitler's anger grew with the rise of the Social Democrats and their growing internationalism, as well as their hate for their own country.
The Social Democrats gained support from the lower classes, and they would disparage the nation and its national pride.
They poisoned what little the people knew or remembered, and poisoned the body-politic of Germany and her national pride.
How can the cinema and the gutter press inculcate knowledge of one's country, especially when childhood education was lacking?
slides.script: This slide illustrates the growing anger Hitler had for the Social Democrats. As he witnessed their rise, it stoked anger for them and their supposed international ties. The lack of national pride and their campaign of falsehoods was a step too far for Hitler and his German nationalist ideals.

slides.title: Understanding Marxism and Jews
content: Hitler began to realize that the social-democratic newspapers revealed the true character of their political system.
They preached liberty, human dignity, and beauty to the intelligentsia, while the daily press used brutal slander to the masses.
The more Hitler learned about Social Democracy, the more his love for his people reawakened, and the more he hated the Jews.
His views on the Jews changed to the belief that their Marxist doctrine repudiates the aristocratic principle of humanity.
slides.script: Here, we'll explore the growing anger Hitler had for Marxism and the Jews. He notes a stark difference between what these Social Democrats preach and the reality of what they represent. It was as a result of learning this that Hitler's belief that the Jew is an enemy of humanity grew.

slides.title: Gassed and Confronted with Revolution
content: A gas attack blinded Hitler near the end of the war, sending him to a hospital in Pasewalk, but his fate was already decided.
Hitler was shocked by the news of the Revolution that spread around the hospital, as he thought it was all a local affair.
A pastor told the people that the Kaiser would no longer wear the crown and that the Fatherland was a republic.
His world collapsed at the revolution; it seemed that all the suffering and hardship of war had come to naught.
slides.script: Here, we'll examine the end of the war, where Hitler's fate would be decided and where he would come to the realization that the hardships had all been for nothing. He notes that the new goal of the war was to bring down all that the German soldier fought for. A new stage in Hitler's life was about to begin.

slides.title: Post-War: A Resolve to Enter Politics
content: Hitler is distraught in the aftermath and, after experiencing this shock, he decided to enter politics.
He felt it was now his duty to save the German people from the perceived injustice.
He is assigned as an instructor for the army to speak about politics to the common soldiers and provide a way of thinking.
He had a natural talent for speaking and met people who would help found his movement in this capacity.
slides.script: Here, we'll explore the seeds of Hitler's political ambition. From his gassed, hospital bed, Hitler came to the realization that it was his duty to enter the political sphere and reverse the damage that had been done. His new position as an instructor in the army gave him the power he would need for action.

slides.title: Investigating the German Worker's Party
content: Assigned to investigate a political association known as the German Worker's Party, with Gottfried Feder speaking.
The association was small and consisted of mostly lower-class people with whom Hitler did not get along.
One of the members gave Hitler a pamphlet that helped him to decide on his path forward.
Hitler, who did not wish to join, was surprised to receive a postcard that invited him to become a member.
slides.script: Now we'll discuss Hitler's joining of the German Worker's Party. As part of his duties, he had to explore the local political organizations, and it was as a result of this investigation that his path forward would soon be made clear. All of the pieces were falling into place...

slides.title: An Audience With the GWP
content: Hitler attended a meeting with the committee of the German Worker's Party, which was attended by the head of the association.
The event was a dull parish club, where the minutes were read and they discussed letters.
However, when a man challenged Feder, Hitler spoke up against the challenge, gaining the respect of Drexler.
Drexler gave Hitler a pamphlet called 'My Political Awakening', after which Hitler resolved to join the group.
slides.script: This slide will highlight the events of that fateful committee meeting where Hitler spoke with the GWP. The events at that tavern forever changed the course of not only Hitler's life, but the course of the world. The meeting was, at first, quite underwhelming, but in speaking up against the challenge, Hitler won Drexler's favor.

slides.title: Joining the Party: Member #7
content: Hitler decided to join the German Worker's Party, which he was invited to do via postcard.
However, he didn't think it would be right to get involved unless it would be everything he dreamed of, so it was a hard choice.
He was numbered 7, thus beginning one of the most important political movements of the 20th century.
Chapter 6 will cover the reflections on the sojourn in Vienna and how a person with nothing can rise to power.
slides.script: This slide summarizes Hitler's decision to join the German Worker's Party. He'd been asked to help and his decision was finally made. He became member number 7, and the world as we know it would never be the same again. Next time, we'll discuss Hitler's post-war policy, and the importance of racialism in government.
